ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I acquired skills in looking at and engaging with art, while learning specifically about the Japanese art tradition as it relates to Japanese screens.
I gained a broad understanding of the techniques and traditions behind Japanese Screens. This class taught me how to close look at works of art.

As a non-art history major, I appreciated learning about visual analysis and practicing these skills through the brief notes. I also learned a lot about Japanese culture, which was an unexpected but meaningful component of the course.
Introduction to Japanese screens and Japanese art
I learnt a huge amount about Japanese painting practices, in particular about Japanese screens, visual culture and storytelling.
I learnt about the function of Japanese screens by looking at their function within the home whilst also as artwork
A deeper appreciation of the themes in Japanese art and specifically, screens.
I learned about the art of Japanese screens, and the history behind them.
I gained much visual analysis knowledge and a greater appreciation for Japanese art.
Sensitivity to Japanese Screens and learning to talk about art
As someone who has always enjoyed art history, but is unfamiliar with Japan, I learned a great deal about Japanese cultural and artistic aesthetics.
I gained a deeper understanding of Japanese sociopolitical history as well as new insights into art analysis.
I learned about Japanese art history, specifically about Byobu screens
How to interpret the complex modality of screens

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lecture can get a bit "meta" at times, but the Professor is what makes this class enjoyable!

I loved how the course assignments were creative and allowed for me to engage with the material in non-traditional ways. I found myself actually looking forward to the assignments and I honestly may have spent more time on the non-traditional, creative assignments than I would have spent on the classic essay assignment. The very small section was great-- I felt like I was able to delve deeply into the topic and connect to it better than compared to other classes with huge sections.

I think this course is wonderful for someone who has little to no art history background, so it's approachability is a strength. However, I was wanting a bit more practice on some technical terms (in Japanese). Perhaps a bit of the class could be focused on memorizing these terms so that when Prof. Yiengpruksawan lectures, it is a bit more clear what she is referring to.
great teacher

Mimi and the TFs were so nice and accommodating, taking into account the potential challenges of online learning and adjusting course requirements as they saw fit. I personally found the subject matter (Japanese screen painting) very interesting. It was also nice to have open-ended assignments, so that I could think and write about the things I was interested in from lectures and readings. Kind of like a "choose your own adventure" type of course!
I love this course. It gave students so much freedom and had such a relaxed learning environment.
This course was exceptional. It was very relaxed, with sections optional but very helpful, and the content clearly explained.
it was slightly repetitive but very interesting content

This course was very low stress, and Professor Mimi always tried to accommodate for the current circumstances. This was the single biggest strength of the course. As far as weaknesses go, honestly, not much to say.

There were so many strengths in that we had the liberty to really take our own understanding of art and Japanese culture into our own hands. We were able to interpret art and gain an understanding for the human condition as well.

I loved everything about this class. There were optional sections to attend, I appreciated the flexibility that we had to meet in break out rooms after the lecture portion of the course, and Mimi was always available to meet. The subject itself was interesting, and the course truly allowed me to freely explore a subject that I had never had the opportunity to explore before.

Terminology and concepts are explained clearly so that even non-Japanese and non-art history students can understand. It would have been better if we could actually see the artworks in person but we couldn't do that due to the pandemic.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having all the lectures recorded was incredible. I loved this option because it allowed me to engage with the material even more deeply than ever before, because I was able to re-listen to lectures, and return to the lectures if I had questions or wanted to hear the prof's comments on a topic again.

I think the online lectures were organized, and the fact they were recorded helped because I could go back and rewatch if I missed anything. I think discussion board on Canvas was really engaging. Overall, I thought the class was well-adapted to COVID-19 restrictions.
I thought the combination of synchronous and asynchronous components was very well thought out, and gave me flexibility to engage with the material at my own pace.
I think this course was great overall. The live lectures that were recorded were great

The flexibility with timings was a huge plus - the recordings of the lecture meant that students in other time zones or with schedule clashes could still take the class. It was a shame that we couldn't see the works in the YUAG in person, but the quality of the images and the explanation of their content was very effective given the circumstances.
success
The switch to virtual lectures with weekly discussions felt seamless. Lectures were recorded in case you couldn't make the time due to conflicts or time zone differences.
section was good

I believe that the weekly blog posts, as well as the format itself (live virtual lecture format for half the class, and then entering break out rooms for the other half the class in seminar-like format) worked perfectly for this course.
The discussion post forums and in-lecture discussions allowed for easy and engaging interactions between students, even despite the pandemic.
It was a live lecture with recordings. It was done well in my opinion.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! The Professor is genuinely one of the most caring and kind professors out there in the Yale bubble.

Absolutely. The material was so interesting and covered a very diverse set of screens and themes. I learned so much. And, Prof Mimi is incredible, extremely knowledgeable, very personable, and clearly passionate about what she teaches. She also very clearly cares about her students and wants them to succeed and be involved with the course.
Yes, I would recommend this to a student who is interested in the arts but has little background in art history. It is approachable and engaging!
yes passionate teacher
Yes!
Yes absolutely!!! Even if you don't know anything about Japanese art, this is a great introduction and Mimi is such an amazing professor.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The works we look at are beautiful, and an understanding of Japanese art has really complemented my visual analysis skills. For art history/ east asian studies students and students outside the major, this is a cracking class that you are sure to get a lot out of. There's no expectation of any existing knowledge of Japanese art or the language, and you are guided through the works by an exceptional professor and group of TAs.
yes it is an interesting class
Yes, low stress, very accommodating and flexible.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student! The material was extremely interesting, and I feel like I learned so much.

Yes! I would recommend this course to anyone. Any art history course is recommended in my opinion but especially this course with Mimi. Japanese art is so beautiful and Japanese screens are an integral part of Japanese culture. Anyone interested in learning about East Asia, Japan or the visual arts should take this course.

Highly recommend. Mimi is such a wonderful professor and is truly knowledgable about the subject. Additionally, it is evident that she really cares about her students' well-being and their ability to learn freely.
Yes, this class is a great introduction to both Japanese history and art analysis. The course material is also very accessible for non-Art/East Asian Studies majors!
Yes I do recommend the class to everyone. It is an interesting class that exposes students to a niche field in art and history.
Yes its a very interesting and engaging course that makes a complex art form accessible.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live lectures are always recorded. After every live lecture, students are sent to smaller breakout rooms with either a TA or Professor Mimi to discuss and examine a Japanese screen.
n/a
Live and recorded lecture with breakout room/seminar discussions after.
break out room
Optional live virtual section; online discussion board
none
Live virtual lecture that was recorded for those who could not attend synchronously, with discussion groups in break-out rooms during lecture and weekly optional seminar-format sections.
none
live virtual lectures in conjunction with recorded lectures for missed days; there were weekly discussions
Weekly live virtual section
We had weekly discussion sections that were live virtual.
Included an optional section each week for further discussion of the material covered in lecture.

It was a live virtual lecture format for half the class, and then we would enter break out rooms for the other half the class in seminar-like format. The lecture portion of the course was always recorded.
Combination of recorded lectures and live virtual lectures.
online discussion forum
Recorded lecture and live virtual lecture
N/A
